thread.title: Starbucks CEO stepping down | wwltv.com
thread.title_full: Starbucks CEO stepping down | wwltv.com

posts.title: Starbucks CEO stepping down | wwltv.com
posts.text:
Starbucks CEO stepping down Charisse Jones / USA TODAY , WWL 8:04 PM. CST December 01, 2016 SEATTLE, WA - MARCH 23: Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz speaks about the Christmas cup controversy during the Starbucks Annual Shareholders Meeting on March 23, 2016 in Seattle, Washington. (Photo: Stephen Brashear, 2016 Getty Images) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST 
Howard Schultz, who helped turn Starbucks into an iconic global brand as well known for its activism as its coffee blends, will step down from the role of CEO in April. 
Schultz will become the company‚Äôs executive chairman, concentrating on ramping up Starbucks Reserve Roasteries, a new premium experience that the company is betting on to boost growth worldwide, as well as the company‚Äôs well-known forays into community activism. Kevin Johnson, the company‚Äôs current president and COO will become the CEO, retaining the title of president. 
‚ÄúIn all my years at Starbucks I have never been more energized or exhilarated about the opportunities that lie ahead,‚Äô‚Äô Schultz said in a conference call Thursday afternoon. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not leaving the company. I‚Äôm here every single day, and I‚Äôm going to contribute to what I consider a significant growth opportunity. ... But Kevin and the team are in charge.‚Äô‚Äô 
It‚Äôs the second time since Schultz bought the Starbucks Coffee Company in the late 1980s that he has stepped down from the role of CEO. He resigned in 2000, only to return to the helm eight years later. 
But ‚Äúthe differences between then and now couldn‚Äôt be greater,‚Äô‚Äô he said, noting that when he returned to the top job in 2008, Starbucks and other companies were riding out the dramatic financial downturn that was the Great Recession. "The management team at that time ... just did not have the capability or experience to really navigate through that difficult period." In recent years, he says, the company has assembled ‚Äúthe strongest leadership team in our history." 
Johnson, who began his career as a systems engineer for IBM, joined the Starbucks board in 2009 and began working at the company in 2015. He previously spent 16 years at Microsoft working on global sales and marketing, then five years in Silicon Valley as CEO of Juniper Networks, a Sunnyvale, Calf.-company that develops networking products. 
It is Johnson‚Äôs deep background in technology that Schultz said will be pivotal for Starbucks‚Äô future growth. Technology can be used to bolster the customer experience, while Schultz focuses on the more premium offerings that will make a visit to Starbucks stand out from other eateries or retailers. 
"We‚Äôll be opening globally in years to come roasteries, reserve stores and reserve bars that will be customer destination venues,‚Äô‚Äô Schultz says. By the end of 2019, the company plans to have unveiled more than 20 roasteries, and it plans to open more than 1,000 reserve stores, a new premium coffee space that will highlight new brewing techniques, and artisanal food offerings. Schultz said that those locations are expected to "deliver twice the unit economics of a typical Starbucks store.'' 
Schultz, who will continue to be chairman of the board, will also continue to spearhead the social causes that have sometimes made him and Starbucks a lightning rod. In 2013 he asked customers not bring firearms into stores. And in 2015, as the nation was grappling with a wave of police shootings of unarmed black men and boys, Starbucks employees were told to write ‚ÄúRace Together‚Äù on cups, with the company saying that it wanted to help spark a discussion about race. 
‚ÄúWe want to use our scale for good,‚Äô‚Äô Schultz said, noting a few of its many initiatives, including hiring over 10,000 veterans and their spouses, and making a dent in the youth unemployment rate by giving thousands fo young people. "We think companies need to do more for the people they serve and the people they employ.‚Äô‚Äô 
Johnson acknowledged that Schultz is a major act to follow. "Howard is among the world‚Äôs most iconic leaders and entrepreneurs,‚Äô‚Äô Johnson said. But, the company's leaders work "well together and have built a foundation of trust, transparency and teamwork.‚Äô‚Äô 
Contributing: Elizabeth Weise

thread.title: Starbucks' CEO transition unlikely to disrupt growth
thread.title_full: Starbucks' CEO transition unlikely to disrupt growth

posts.title: Starbucks' CEO transition unlikely to disrupt growth
posts.text:
By Sruthi Ramakrishnan, Reuters December 2, 2016 ‚Ä¢ Reprints 
Starbucks Chief Executive Howard Schultz's decision to step down is unlikely to disrupt growth at the world's biggest coffee chain as his successor Kevin Johnson is well suited to take the helm, analysts said. 
Starbucks Corp said on Thursday that Schultz would step down as CEO on April 3 to focus on new high-end coffee shops, handing the top job to Chief Operating Officer Johnson, a long-time technology executive. 
The company's shares were down 2.6 % in premarket trading as investors worried that the legendary CEO's exit would spell trouble for the company. 
The last time Schultz stepped down as CEO‚Äîin 2000‚Äîthe company's shares had plunged. 
Schultz returned to the top job in 2008. Since then the company's annual sales have more than doubled and its stock has risen six-fold. 
"Unlike the period surrounding Mr. Schultz's previous departure, we believe the company is transitioning to a new CEO during a period of strength, with a solid macro-economic backdrop, a strong leadership team, and a robust pipeline of innovation in technology, food, beverages," RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer wrote in a note. 
Johnson's experience of working with Schultz for nearly two years as well as his technology background, including stints at Microsoft Corp and Juniper Networks Inc, sets him up for the job, analysts said. 
Schultz said on Thursday that he had personally asked Johnson to take the CEO job, highlighting Johnson's technology chops at a time when the company is trying to project itself as a pioneer in mobile payments technology. 
Starbucks was the first to push into mobile ordering and payments through its app, allowing customers to avoid standing in long lines and forcing rivals like Dunkin' Brands Group Inc and Panera Bread Co to follow suit. 
The mobile payments strategy has proved hugely successful‚Äîa quarter of all transactions in Starbucks' latest quarter was through mobile phones. 
Starbucks' quarterly revenue has risen at a pace of least 7 % since 2009, much faster than that of Dunkin' and McDonald's Corp. 
"While we acknowledge that Schultz is without question one of the strongest and most visionary leaders in the consumer/retail world, we believe the succession planning put in place several years ago assures the recent exceptional performance will likely continue," Wells Fargo Securities analyst Bonnie Herzog said in a note. 
Schultz's plans to "premiumize" the Starbucks brand should allow the broader store network to continue to thrive, Herzog added. 
The outgoing CEO said on Thursday that in his new role he would focus on building the ultra-premium Starbucks Reserve stores and showcase Roastery and Tasting Rooms around the world. 
These efforts come as Starbucks is trying to stave off competition from super-premium coffee rivals such as Blue Bottle and Intelligentsia. 
The company opened its first Reserve Roastery and Tasting Room in 2014 in Seattle‚ÄîStarbucks' birthplace‚Äîto roast and sell limited-supply Reserve coffees. It plans to open three more in Shanghai, New York and Tokyo. About the Author

posts.text:
Starbucks CEO steps down to focus on high-end coffee, shares fall Thu Dec 1, 2016 6:53pm EST [ - ] Text [ + ] 
By Lisa Baertlein and Gayathree Ganesan 
(Reuters) - Starbucks Corp (SBUX.O: Quote ) co-founder Howard Schultz will step down as chief executive to focus on new high-end coffee shops, handing the top job to Chief Operating Officer Kevin Johnson, a long-time technology executive. 
Schultz, who will become executive chairman in April 2017, said he would focus on building ultra-premium Reserve stores and showcase Roastery and Tasting Rooms around the world as well as setting the brand's "social impact agenda" that includes sending employees to college and recruiting veterans. 
Starbucks had signaled the change in July, but its shares fell 3.6 percent to $56.41 in extended trading on Thursday, as investors recalled the company's decline after Schultz handed over the reins in 2000. He returned in 2008. 
"Having him step down as CEO raised the anxiety level," said Stephens analyst Will Slabaugh, who said that Schultz is the heart and soul of the brand, its entrepreneurial leader and its savior. 
"We're in a much better position on every level," said Schultz, who returned for his second stint as CEO in the depths of the "Great Recession," when Starbucks' stock was trading below $10. Late last year, it hit an all-time high above $60. Schultz has put Starbucks in the national spotlight, asking customers not to bring guns into stores and urging conversations on race relations. 
Many of the campaigns have generated controversy, but analysts have not seen a hit to financial results and the efforts have raised the profile of the coffee company and cemented Schultz's status as a national figure. 
"The idea that he's replaceable, I think that's erroneous," said Bill Smead, CEO of Smead Capital Management in Seattle, which owns Starbucks shares. He compared the change to the retirement of long-time McDonald's Corp (MCD.N: Quote ) CEO Ray Kroc, who turned a handful of hamburger stands into the world's biggest restaurant company. 
The announcement on Thursday also came as investors worry about the restaurant industry's stubborn traffic declines. Starbucks has held up better than most, but it has not been immune. Continued...

posts.title: Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz to step down | WPMT FOX43
posts.text:
Howard Schultz, the CEO of Starbucks, steps down. √ó Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz to step down Howard Schultz, the CEO of Starbucks, steps down. 
NEW YORK ‚Äî Howard Schultz, the visionary leader of Starbucks, will be stepping down next year as CEO of the iconic coffee giant. 
Schultz‚Äôs surprise decision to step aside as the leader of Starbucks sent the stock sinking 3% in after-hours trading on Thursday. 
Starbucks said Schultz isn‚Äôt going away completely. Effective April 3, he will become executive chairman, where he will focus on innovation, the design of Starbucks locations and the company‚Äôs social impact initiatives. Current chief operating officer Kevin Johnson, a tech industry veteran, will replace Schultz as CEO. 
‚ÄúThis is a good thing. I‚Äôm not leaving the company,‚Äù Schultz told CNN‚Äôs Poppy Harlow by phone on Thursday. 
Even though Schultz hadn‚Äôt telegraphed the move, the CEO said he had been planning the move for at least a year. 
Asked if he‚Äôs going to Washington, Schultz laughed and said, ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm not going to Washington.‚Äù 
Instead, Schultz emphasized a desire to focus on the company‚Äôs social impact initiatives. 
‚ÄúGiven the state of things in the country, there is a need to help those left behind,‚Äù Schultz told CNN. 
Separately, in a conference call, Schultz said Johnson brings ‚Äúunparalleled understanding of market dynamics‚Äù and he deserves a ‚Äútremendous amount of credit‚Äù for the company‚Äôs recent record results. 
Schultz joined Starbucks in 1982 as director of retail operations and he helped turn the company into a retail powerhouse and an iconic American brand. He stepped down as CEO in April 2000 to concentrate on executing the company‚Äôs global strategy. 
But Starbucks struggled without him at the helm and seemed to have lost its way. Schultz returned as CEO in 2008 and helped guide the coffee giant through the Great Recession and get it back on track. Today, Starbucks is valued at $84 billion and it has more than 24,000 retail stores in 70 countries.

thread.title: Starbucks: Howard Schultz OK With Donald Trump Supporters
thread.title_full: Starbucks: Howard Schultz OK With Donald Trump Supporters

posts.author: John Kell
posts.title: Starbucks: Howard Schultz OK With Donald Trump Supporters
posts.text:
Outgoing Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz publicly backed Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton for president this year. And although she lost to President-elect Donald Trump and a few angry Trump fans launched a #TrumpCup protest at Starbucks, Schultz doesn‚Äôt think the brand has a problem with Trump supporters.
In an interview with CNBC on Friday, just one day after Schultz announced he would step down as CEO in 2017, the coffee giant guru was asked if his brand was at all at odds with those that supported Trump‚Äôs candidacy.
The Starbucks sbux chief essentially argued that coffees and teas are bipartisan.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think on any level that the brand or what we represent is at odds with the president elect or his supporters,‚Äù Schultz told CNBC . ‚Äú90 million customers a week are going through Starbucks stores and I assume many of them voted for Donald Trump.‚Äù
The comments from Schultz are important as Starbucks has been subjected to one of many post-election boycotts that have targeted well-known consume brands. A #BoycottStarbucks hashtag floated around social media channels for some time now and the #TrumpCup campaign percolated after a viral video showed a white male Trump supporter yelling at a barista, claiming he was subjected to anti-white discrimination .
Starbucks has been at the epicenter of the election for some time now‚Äîmostly because Schultz has been very vocal. Early this year he lamented the tone of the election, calling it ‚Äúa circus of yelling bombastic attacks.‚Äù He publicly backed Clinton in September, predicted she would win in October, and said he was ‚Äústunned‚Äù by Trump‚Äôs win a day after the election.
Schultz on Friday told CNBC that he was hopeful President-elect Trump would be successful. But he also stressed that he personally, as well as Schultz‚Äôs successor Kevin Johnson and the Starbucks board, was hopeful that the Trump administration would address social issues that had been overlooked by past Republican administrations.
While Schultz didn‚Äôt specify what social issues were most important to him, he has been vocal about some hot-button topics, including gay marriage, race and diversity , access to health care, and gun control. Most of his stances on those issues have been arguably very progressive.
One thing that was left unsaid in the wake of the news that Schultz would step down as CEO next year: would he ever run for public office?
The 63-year-old executive said as recent as last month that he had no interest in becoming a politician. And as of now, the plan for Schultz is to steer Starbucks push into more premium retail experiences, inspired by the success of the company‚Äôs Roastery in Seattle.

posts.title: Starbucks: Schultz to step down as CEO, focus on innovation | WTNH Connecticut News
posts.text:
Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window) In this file photo a customer enjoys a coffee at Starbucks. (AP Photo/Alan Diaz, File) 
NEW YORK (AP) ‚Äî Starbucks Chairman Howard Schultz is stepping down as CEO of the coffee chain he joined more than 30 years ago and transformed into a globally known brand. 
Schultz will become executive chairman in April to focus on innovation such as high-end shops and social impact activities, the Seattle-based chain announced Thursday. Kevin Johnson, who was named president and chief operating officer last year, will be chief executive as of April 3. 
Since returning as the company‚Äôs CEO in 2008, Schultz is credited with turning around Starbucks‚Äô fortunes. He has overseen the expansion of the chain‚Äôs food and beverage offerings and the growth of its popular loyalty program and mobile app. 
Starbucks has credited the rewards program and app for helping consistently increase sales in the U.S., although growth has slowed more recently and traffic slipped in the latest quarter. Schultz has said such technology adaptions will become increasingly critical for brick-and-mortar retail businesses to thrive as shopping habits change. 
Investor concerns about the change sent shares of Starbucks down 3.6 percent to $56.41 in after-hours trading. 
During a conference call about the CEO announcement, an analyst called Schultz a ‚Äúmaster merchant‚Äù who has been able to determine and even stimulate ‚Äúwhat the Starbucks customer wants and needs‚Äù and asked if that ‚Äúmerchant gene‚Äù would still be present in those leading the company. Another noted that Starbucks struggled after Schultz stepped away as CEO in 2000, and asked what was different this time. 
Schultz, 63, said Starbucks has built a strong leadership team in recent years. He also noted that he is not leaving the company, and will be working on developing the Starbucks Reserve Roasteries, which are high-end retail concepts featuring coffee beans and drinks like ‚Äúcold brew‚Äù coffee. Schultz called it the ‚Äúnext wave of retail innovation.‚Äù 
‚ÄúBut Kevin and the team are in charge,‚Äù Schultz said. 
In a note issued before Starbucks‚Äô announcement, RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer said he believed the company can regain its domestic sales momentum by focusing on expanding its rewards program and the changes it is making to its food menu. 
Over the years, Schultz has said that people expect more from public companies, and has aligned himself and Starbucks with social issues like race and jobs for underprivileged youth. In September, he publicly endorsed Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton in an interview with CNN, and did not rule out running for office at some point. 
In a call with employees, Schultz said the company was not perfect, but it was authentic. Starbucks was criticized for having baristas write, ‚Äúrace together‚Äù on cups last year in the wake of police shootings ‚Äî a move Schultz told employees he‚Äôd do again ‚Äúin a heartbeat.‚Äù 
‚ÄúIt was one of my proudest moments,‚Äù he said. 
Johnson, 56, will take charge of the company‚Äôs global business and operations. He joined the Starbucks board in 2009, and spent years at technology companies including 16 years with Microsoft and five as Juniper Networks CEO. 
Wells Fargo analyst Bonnie Herzog said she believes Johnson‚Äôs technology background will help ensure Starbucks‚Äô digital initiatives will remain a priority. Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. Share this:

Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window) FILE - In this Wednesday, March 23, 2016, file photo, Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz walks in front of a photo of Starbucks baristas, at the coffee company's annual shareholders meeting in Seattle. Starbucks announced Thursday, Dec. 1, 2016, that Schultz is stepping down from the coffee chain that he joined more than 30 years ago, and that Kevin Johnson will become chief executive as of April 3, 2017. Schultz will become executive chairman on that date to focus on innovation and social impact activities, among other things. (AP Photo/Ted S. Warren, File) 
NEW YORK (AP) ‚Äî Starbucks says CEO Howard Schultz, who transformed the chain into a global coffee brand, is stepping down from that role at the chain that he joined more than 30 years ago. 
The Seattle-based company announced Thursday that Kevin Johnson, who was named president and chief operating officer last year, will become chief executive as of April 3. 
Schultz, currently chairman and CEO, will become executive chairman to focus on innovation and social impact activities, among other things. 
In a message to Starbucks employees, Schultz spoke of his ‚Äúenduring love‚Äù for the company and called himself ‚Äúincredibly excited‚Äù to work on projects such as the expansion of premium Starbucks Roasteries around the world. 
He is credited with turning around the coffee chain‚Äôs fortunes since returning as its CEO in 2008. Schultz, 63, has overseen the expansion of the company‚Äôs popular loyalty program and mobile app and worked to expand food and beverage offerings. FILE ‚Äì In this Wednesday, March 23, 2016, file photo, Kevin Johnson, president and chief operating officer of Starbucks Corp., holds up one of the coffee company‚Äôs prepaid Visa debit cards, at the company‚Äôs annual shareholders meeting in Seattle. Starbucks announced Thursday, Dec. 1, 2016, that CEO Howard Schultz is stepping down from the coffee chain that he joined more than 30 years ago, and that Johnson will become chief executive as of April 3, 2017. Schultz will become executive chairman on that date to focus on innovation and social impact activities, among other things. (AP Photo/Ted S. Warren, File) 
Speaking on a conference call, Johnson called Schultz one of the world‚Äôs ‚Äúmost iconic leaders and entrepreneurs.‚Äù 
The company‚Äôs sales have grown impressively in the U.S., although they‚Äôve slowed more recently. 
During an interview with CNN in September, Schultz publicly endorsed Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, and did not rule out running for office at some point. In his message to employees Thursday, he said he planned to extend his ‚Äúfocus on our social impact agenda.‚Äù 
Shares of Starbucks slid 3.6 percent to $56.44 in after-hours trading. 
Johnson, 56, will take charge of the company‚Äôs global business and operations. He joined the Starbucks board in 2009 and has spent years at technology companies including 16 years with Microsoft and five as Juniper Networks CEO. Share this:

Starbucks Corp said on Thursday that Schultz would step down as CEO on April 3 to focus on new high-end coffee shops, handing the top job to Chief Operating Officer Johnson, a long-time technology executive. 
Watch what else is in the news 
The company‚Äôs shares were down 2.5 percent at $57.02 on Friday as investors worried that the exit of one of Wall Street‚Äôs most regarded CEOs would spell trouble for the company. Analysts, however, downplayed these concerns. ‚ÄúHoward can‚Äôt be in that position forever,‚Äù Morningstar analyst R.J. Hottovy told Reuters. 
Hottovy said the timing of the handoff made sense because the company had a strong management team and Johnson had more retail experience than the market was giving him credit for. Johnson worked with Schultz for nearly two years and has been on Starbucks‚Äô board since 2009. 
He also has a strong technology background, including stints at Microsoft Corp and Juniper Networks Inc, which sets him up to lead Starbucks at a time when the company is looking to project itself as a pioneer in mobile payments technology. 
‚ÄúJohnson appears to have been an important behind-the-scenes contributor to Starbucks‚Äô post-recession turnaround, and his background in technology should position him well,‚Äù Bernstein analyst Sara Senatore said in a research note. To be sure, the last time Schultz stepped down as CEO ‚Äì in 2000 ‚Äì the company‚Äôs shares had plunged. 
Schultz returned to the top job in 2008. Since then the company‚Äôs annual sales have more than doubled and its stock has risen six-fold. 
‚ÄúUnlike the period surrounding Mr. Schultz‚Äôs previous departure, we believe the company is transitioning to a new CEO during a period of strength, with a solid macro-economic backdrop, a strong leadership team, and a robust pipeline of innovation in technology, food, beverages,‚Äù RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer wrote in a note. 
Starbucks was the first to push into mobile ordering and payments through its app, allowing customers to avoid standing in long lines and forcing rivals like Dunkin‚Äô Brands Group Inc and Panera Bread Co to follow suit. The mobile payments strategy has proved hugely successful ‚Äì a quarter of all transactions in Starbucks‚Äô latest quarter was through mobile phones. 
Starbucks‚Äô quarterly revenue has risen at a pace of at least 7 percent since 2009, much faster than that of Dunkin‚Äô and McDonald‚Äôs Corp. Wells Fargo Securities analyst Bonnie Herzog said in a note that Schultz‚Äôs plans to ‚Äúpremiumize‚Äù the Starbucks brand should allow the broader store network to continue to thrive. 
The outgoing CEO said on Thursday that in his new role he would focus on building the ultra-premium Starbucks Reserve stores and showcase Roastery and Tasting Rooms around the world, which analysts said was a worthwhile endeavor. Starbucks is trying to stave off competition from super-premium coffee rivals such as Blue Bottle and Intelligentsia. 
The company opened its first Reserve Roastery and Tasting Room in 2014 in Seattle ‚Äì Starbucks‚Äô birthplace ‚Äì to roast and sell limited-supply Reserve coffees. It plans to open three more in Shanghai, New York and Tokyo. Best of Express

thread.title: Freed from CEO role, Schultz to focus on Starbucks upscale push, Consumer - THE BUSINESS TIMES
thread.title_full: Freed from CEO role, Schultz to focus on Starbucks upscale push, Consumer - THE BUSINESS TIMES

posts.title: Freed from CEO role, Schultz to focus on Starbucks upscale push, Consumer - THE BUSINESS TIMES
posts.text:
Freed from CEO role, Schultz to focus on Starbucks upscale push Howard Schultz is ready for his next project: Starbucks 2.0. PHOTO: REUTERS Dec 3, 2016 1:37 PM 
[NEW YORK] Howard Schultz is ready for his next project: Starbucks 2.0. 
Mr Schultz, who will become executive chairman when he steps down as chief executive officer at Starbucks Corp next year, says he'll focus on his three-pronged bet that the world's largest coffee chain needs to become even more upscale. The program includes a line of premium coffee called Reserve, as many as 1,000 cafes that will showcase the new brand and flagship stores as large as 20,000 square feet called Roasteries. 
The 63-year-old executive, a billionaire who built a caffeine empire by bringing Italian coffee culture to the American mainstream, will soon be free from the daily grind of running a US$21 billion business. That will allow him to devote his attention to a key growth initiative that's been slow to gain momentum over the past two years. 
"When you're making an investment and taking a risk like this, there's no better person to spearhead it than Howard," said Darren Tristano, president of Technomic Inc, which tracks the restaurant industry. "He has a very high chance of succeeding in this type of role and helping the brand evolve." 
With more and more shopping done online, Mr Schultz has said he wants to emulate the brick-and-mortar retail experiences offered by innovators like Nike and Apple. Starbucks opened the first Roastery location two years ago, a 15,000-square-foot emporium in its hometown of Seattle, and is planning others in New York, Shanghai and Tokyo. The menu includes small-lot coffee from around the world that can sell for more than US$20 a pound. 
The cavernous stores, where customers can watch coffee being roasted on site, are envisioned as high-end flagships for the company, but rollout has been slowed by high construction costs and trouble finding suitable real estate. 
Analysts are skeptical that a handful of Roasteries can move the needle for the massive company, which operates more than 16,000 cafes worldwide. Instead, they say financial growth is expected to come from the Reserve locations. The new cafes are planned to be similar to the Roasteries but without the actual bean-cooking operation. 
It's part of a move by Mr Schultz to add different store concepts around the world and reimagine the 45-year-old chain. 
"He's always had grand visions for where Starbucks can go," said Jennifer Bartashus, an analyst at Bloomberg Intelligence. "The ability for him to separate himself from the day-to-day running of the company and focus on big ideas is well within his wheelhouse." Starbucks said Mr Schultz wasn't available to be interviewed for this article. 
To be sure, there are risks in going more upscale. Some customers already balk at paying more than US$5 for a coffee drink, and with rising health-care costs and stagnant wage growth causing anxiety among US consumers, the effort could run into headwinds, particularly if there's an economic downturn, Ms Bartashus said. 
Starbucks needs the Reserve cafes to work because there's more and more competition from local and regional chains that are pulling in younger customers. To secure the next generation of consumers, Starbucks has to convince millennials that it's a cool place for coffee - a difficult proposition after four decades that saw the company grow to become a mainstream brand like McDonald's. 
Starbucks is also pushing into the Chinese market, with plans to open hundreds of stores. Growing domestically won't be easy given the rise of competitors such as Blue Bottle, Stumptown and Intelligentsia, independent chains that cater to a premium audience. 
It's those chains that are pressuring Starbucks, in addition to mainstream competitors like Dunkin' Donuts or Coffee & Bagels, a new chain being developed by JAB Holding Co. The European investment firm backed by Austria's billionaire Reimann family has used acquisitions, including Stumptown and Krispy Kreme, to build its own coffee empire. 
When Mr Schultz acquired the then-six-unit chain in the late 1980s, it wasn't typical for Americans to spend hours in a cafe sipping expensive coffee. That changed, and with Starbucks established as a daily ritual for millions of Americans, Mr Schultz is once again focused on changing their habits. 
The move upscale is in line with where the restaurant has been heading in recent years, and it helps that Starbucks sells a product that most customers consume daily and consider an affordable luxury, said Peter Saleh, an analyst at BTIG Research. 
"Being a premium brand is where it's at in this industry," he said. "People gravitate to more and more expensive coffee." 
BLOOMBERG

thread.title: Starbucks CEO says the company isn‚Äôt anti-Trump: ‚ÄòWe all want the president-elect to do well‚Äô
thread.title_full: Starbucks CEO says the company isn‚Äôt anti-Trump: ‚ÄòWe all want the president-elect to do well‚Äô - The Washington Post

posts.author: Amy B Wang
posts.title: Starbucks CEO says the company isn‚Äôt anti-Trump: ‚ÄòWe all want the president-elect to do well‚Äô
posts.text:
Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz speaks at the Starbucks Annual Shareholders Meeting on Mar. 23 in Seattle. (Stephen Brashear/Getty Images)
Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz, a vocal critic of Donald Trump during the election, said he is not concerned about the effect of the president-elect ‚Äî or of his supporters ‚Äî on the massive coffee chain‚Äôs business.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not spending a lot of time on the cause and the effect of the Trump administration,‚Äù Schultz said Friday on CNBC . ‚ÄúObviously we all want the president-elect to do well, but Starbucks is going to have to do what we do based on the things that we can control.‚Äù
Throughout the presidential campaign, Schultz made it no secret that he supported Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton , formally endorsing her in September. In a letter to Starbucks staff after Election Day, Schultz admitted he was ‚Äústunned‚Äù when Trump won ‚Äî and called on Starbucks ‚Äúpartners‚Äù to choose to treat others with kindness, compassion and respect.
‚ÄúWe cannot know what the precise impact will be on our country and the rest of the world,‚Äù Schultz wrote then . ‚ÄúI am hopeful that we will overcome the vitriol and division of this unprecedented election season.‚Äù
After the bitter and divisive election came to an end last month, there have been numerous incidents reported at various Starbucks stores involving Trump supporters.
Recently, video of Florida resident David Sanguesa berating a Starbucks barista went viral . Sanguesa claimed afterward that he had been the victim of ‚Äúanti-white discrimination‚Äù and that the employee refused to serve him because he was a Trump supporter. (‚ÄúBecause I voted for Trump! Trump! You lost! Now give me my money back,‚Äù Sanguesa can be heard shouting at the barista in the video. ‚ÄúWhat is your name? I want your name. I want your card. You‚Äôre garbage. You‚Äôre complete trash.‚Äù)
[ ‚ÄòI voted for Trump! You lost!‚Äô: White Starbucks customer accuses barista of ‚Äòdiscrimination‚Äô ]
A witness said Sanguesa simply got angry because his coffee order took too long.
Around the same time, video surfaced of a Starbucks barista at a different location refusing to write ‚ÄúTrump‚Äù on someone‚Äôs cup . Soon afterward, Los Angeles political consultant Tim Treadstone urged his social-media followers to launch ‚ÄúOperation #TrumpCup‚Äù ‚Äî that is, to visit Starbucks, ask them to write ‚ÄúTrump‚Äù on their cups and to take video if any employees refused.
A man who claimed to be a Trump voter was filmed accusing a female Starbucks employee in Miami of "discrimination" on Nov. 16. (Twitter/Jorge de C√°rdenas) On CNBC, Schultz directly addressed questions of whether such incidents might indicate Starbucks and its corporate values meant the chain was ‚Äúat odds‚Äù with Trump and his supporters.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think on any level that the brand or what we represent is at odds with the president-elect or his supporters,‚Äù Schultz told CNBC. ‚Äú90 million customers a week are going through Starbucks stores and I assume many of them voted for Donald Trump.‚Äù
He added that the business needed to separate its prospects ‚Äúfrom the Trump administration and the momentum in the stock market‚Äù but would also continue to push on ‚Äúa number of social issues.‚Äù
Schultz did not elaborate on what those issues might be, only saying that they have not been addressed by Republican administrations in the past and that he hoped Trump would address them in his administration.
‚ÄúI think that as we go forward we will have an active voice in demonstrating the moral courage to address things that we think are important to the promise of America and the American dream,‚Äù Schultz said.
[ A Starbucks barista refused to write ‚ÄòTrump‚Äô on a cup. How his supporters are striking back. ]
His comments were in line with Schultz‚Äôs long record of getting involved in social or political issues, sometimes at the risk of alienating customers.
Last year, Starbucks urged baristas to write ‚ÄúRace Together‚Äù on the sides of its coffee cups, in an effort to engage customers in difficult conversations about race relations in America. The campaign sparked criticism and even ridicule online but had seemingly little effect at the store level . And each year, whether intentionally or not, Starbucks finds itself in the middle of a heated debate over what, exactly, the color of its holiday coffee cup is supposed to mean .
Starbucks‚Äô plain-red holiday cup last year attracted the ire of none other than Trump himself, who suggested to his supporters at a rally last November to boycott the coffee chain .
‚ÄúDid you read about Starbucks?‚Äù Trump asked the crowd in Springfield, Ill., to loud boos. ‚ÄúNo more ‚ÄòMerry Christmas‚Äô at Starbucks. No more. ‚Ä¶ Maybe we should boycott Starbucks.‚Äù
Starbucks is no stranger to such cultural debates, as The Washington Post‚Äôs Maura Judkis noted :
The culture wars come every December, fueled by peppermint mochas and venti soy lattes. The battleground is Starbucks. It‚Äôs always Starbucks, isn‚Äôt it? No one is complaining that the blue-and-brown holiday cups at Caribou Coffee take the ‚ÄúChrist‚Äù out of Christmas. No one is telling the Olive Garden hostess that their name is ‚ÄúTrump‚Äù so that she will have to call out ‚ÄúTrump, party of three!‚Äù
Religion. Politics. The Bill of Rights. They all converge here, in front of a glass case full of cake pops.
Schultz will step aside next April to focus on other Starbucks corporate initiatives, the company announced last Thursday . Kevin Johnson, the company‚Äôs chief operating officer, will take over as CEO then. Schultz said he plans to stay on as chairman.
Read more:
‚ÄòWe have a culture war to win‚Äô: Why Starbucks cups always stir up controversy
‚ÄòAnd I voted for Trump! So there!‚Äô: Woman accuses black Michaels employees of discrimination
‚ÄòDo not say mean things‚Äô: Kids are writing to Donald Trump, asking him to be a kind president

thread.title: Starbucks CEO Leaving Could Be Bad for the Bonds, Too - Income Investing - Barrons.com
thread.title_full: Starbucks CEO Leaving Could Be Bad for the Bonds, Too - Income Investing - Barrons.com

posts.author: Amey Stone
posts.title: Starbucks CEO Leaving Could Be Bad for the Bonds, Too - Income Investing - Barrons.com
posts.text:
News, analysis and commentary on income-generating investments. Search Income Investing2 December 2, 2016, 5:48 P.M. ET Starbucks CEO Leaving Could Be Bad for the Bonds, Too By Amey Stone 
Shares of Starbucks ( SBUX ) fell 2.2% to $57.21 Friday after CEO Howard Schultz announced Thursday that he would be stepping down as head of the coffee company . Kevin Johnson , the current chief operating officer, will assume the CEO job next April. 
The bonds didn‚Äôt show as much reaction, but were negative nonetheless. The price of the 2.45% coupon senior secured notes maturing in 2026, for example, fell from $95.59 to $94.94, according to Bloomberg. The yield judged up to 3% from just below that level. 
Even though Moody‚Äôs analyst William Fahy didn‚Äôt change his rating, he did issue a report pointing to Schultz‚Äôs departure as ‚Äúcredit negative‚Äù because it ‚Äúcreates uncertainty‚Äù at the company. He writes further: 
Despite Kevin Johnson‚Äôs extensive experience, which includes being a Starbucks board member for the past seven years and his daily involvement as COO for the past two years, the exceptional success, insight and vision of founder Howard Schultz is not easily replaced. This was previously evident when he stepped down as CEO in 2000 and the company‚Äôs fortunes subsequently hit a difficult performance period. Since Schultz returned in 2008, Starbucks has become a much larger, more diverse and financially stronger company. While we do not anticipate any changes to Starbuck‚Äôs strategic initiatives or targeted financial policies, it is still too early to know whether Johnson can maintain the kind of momentum and vision that Schultz brought to the role. 
Moody‚Äôs rates Starbucks A2, a mid-level of investment grade, with a stable outlook ‚Äî for now at least.

posts.title: Starbucks Store Co-Supervisor
posts.text: By continuing you agree to Monster's Privacy Policy , Terms of Use and use of cookies . Starbucks Store Co-Supervisor at North Carolina State Univ. Raleigh, NC About the Job Essential Job Duties: This position will supervise the daily operations in a University Starbucks location during service hours to ensure NC State Dining and Starbucks standards of excellent customer service and food and drink quality are being met, while maintaining all safety and sanitation policies and procedures during the shift. There will be two supervisors for this location and they will work different shifts to provide solid supervision during all shifts that the location is open. This position is responsible for the coordination, training, and discipline of staff, students, and temporary labor. Responsibilities will include: Oversees food service unit operations and supervises a staff of employees to ensure guest service and food and drink quality is at an exceptional level, according to Starbucks and University Dining standards Coordinates specialized menu and promotions Schedules staff and makes staff assignments daily following strict Starbucks procedures Performs food production administrative work including purchasing and inventory controls. Must meet assigned budget requirements for food and labor. Will be required to create weekly flash reports Ensures that all State and Departmental Health Standards are being followed. Reports concerns to Food Service Manager for the unit. Orders food and non-food products using the C-Bord food ordering system and Starbucks ordering system Monitors all areas of the location to ensure customer needs are being met and that employees are responsive to customer requests and expectations Monitors work of staff and assesses when improvement/training is needed. Will be responsible for training all new employees, complete and retain certification paperwork for each employee on staff Must hold all employees accountable for delivering excellent customer service Responsible for setting up and closing registers following cash handling procedures. This position must meet all expectations of Starbucks in order to be successful in this position. Other Work/Responsibilities: This position is considered critical and must report to work during adverse weather conditions even if the University is closed. May be required to work overtime and some holidays. Minimum Experience/Education: High School diploma or equivalency and one year of experience in food preparation or service activities in a commercial kitchen; or an equivalent combination of training and experience. Departmental Required Skills: Previous experience working in a coffee house or similar operation Ability to lead and motivate a team of employees Excellent customer service skills Strong communication skills Basic skills and familiarity with MS Windows and the ability to learn new software Must have a sense of urgency and ability to meet strict deadlines Strong problem solving skills Ability to manage effectively and multitask in a fast paced environment Position requires constant standing/walking, occasional pushing, pulling, lifting or carrying up to 30 lbs occasionally and 60 lbs on rare instances, with or without reasonable accommodation Preferred Experience, Skills, Training/Education: -Previous experience as a supervisor in a coffee house -At least two years of food service supervisor experience -Basic cash handling skills Necessary Licenses or Certifications: ServSafe certificate or ability to obtain within 90 days of employment. Must obtain Starbucks Advanced Store Trainer certification within 30 days of employment. Certifications must be maintained as a condition of employment. About the Department/Unit: NC State Dining provides campus wide food services to students, staff, and faculty on the NC State University Campus. NC State Dining operates 30+ dining areas, seven convenience stores, campus concessions, a nutritional counseling center and Rave! Catering. Campus Enterprises is NC State University‚Äôs lead division of retail and hospitality organizations ‚Äî NC State Dining, Wolfpack Outfitters, Trademark Licensing, Lonnie Poole Golf Course, University Student Centers (Witherspoon, Thompson, Price, and Talley), and the Wolfpack One Card Services. Each unit shares a common goal: deliver quality and efficient services with dedicated financial support for student services and scholarships. AA/EEO: NC State University is an equal opportunity and affirmative action employer. All qualified applicants will receive consideration for employment without regard to race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity, age, sexual orientation, genetic information, status as an individual with a disability, or status as a protected veteran. Individuals with disabilities requiring disability-related accommodations in the application and interview process, please call 919-515-3148. Final candidates are subject to criminal & sex offender background checks. Some vacancies also require credit or motor vehicle checks. If highest degree is from an institution outside of the U.S., final candidates are required to have their degree verified at "www.wes.org":http//wes.org. Degree must be obtained prior to start date. NC State University participates in E-Verify. Federal law requires all employers to verify the identity and employment eligibility of all persons hired to work in the United States. To apply, please go to https://jobs.ncsu.edu/postings/75695

thread.title_full: Starbucks Near Inland Regional Center Marks Terror Attack Anniversary With Message to First Responders | KTLA

posts.author: Los Angeles Times
posts.title: Starbucks Near Inland Regional Center Marks Terror Attack Anniversary With Message to First Responders | KTLA
posts.text:
Email 
In the wake of last year‚Äôs terror attack, a San Bernardino Starbucks near the Inland Regional Center because a central meeting place. 
Police and first responders took breaks there, and many journalists wrote stories and transmitted photos and information from there. 
Employees had a special message for the first responders on Friday, written on a board at the coffee house. 
‚ÄúLet us remember the loved ones lost too soon and the first responders of the attack,‚Äù the message said. ‚ÄúSan Bernardino Strong, Always.‚Äù

Schultz is being replaced by former Microsoft senior exec Kevin Johnson, who will become the new CEO. 
In a statement, Schultz said the move ‚Äúideally positions Starbucks to continue profitably growing our core business around the world into the future.‚Äù

posts.title: The Unofficial Ranking of This Year's Starbucks Red Cups
posts.text:
The Unofficial Ranking of This Year's Starbucks Red Cups Spoon University 2 days ago Katie Andrade
Red Cup Season is finally here! In order to combat the drama over the 2015 holiday cups, which many complained were not Christmas-y enough, Starbucks decided to leave this year's design in the hands of their loyal customers.
Last December, the company encouraged people to send in their holiday cup designs via Instagram. They received over 1,200 submissions within eight days and managed to narrow it down to 13 different designs.
For the first time ever, Starbucks will have multiple holiday cups that all share a similar theme and color scheme. Each cup size has a few different designs and are mixed together to create a fun element of surprise for customers.
Since the cups unveiling in stores on November 10th, it is clear that everyone has their favorites. I even heard one girl ask for a different cup because she didn‚Äôt like the design she received (and I‚Äôm sure she‚Äôs not the first).
That is why I decided that for the sake of keeping the red cup drama alive, I would (unofficially) rank the holiday cups from my least favorite to favorite design.
Keep in mind that this ranking is based on my own preferences and I am aware that many won't agree with me. That's what makes this year's holiday cups so special because it gives everyone the opportunity to find the one that speaks to them.

thread.title: Howard Schultz Says Goodbye to His Starbucks Empire - The New Yorker
thread.title_full: Howard Schultz Says Goodbye to His Starbucks Empire - The New Yorker

posts.author: Evan Osnos
posts.title: Howard Schultz Says Goodbye to His Starbucks Empire - The New Yorker
posts.text:
Howard Schultz Says Goodbye to His Starbucks Empire By , 11:47 A.M. The departing Starbucks C.E.O. Howard Schultz‚Äôs narrative about his company is one of excellence and focus, but it‚Äôs really one of unrelenting expansion. Credit PHOTOGRAPH BY SPENCER PLATT / GETTY In the summer of 1995, when my parents told my sister and me that we‚Äôd be moving to Seattle, I started listening to Nirvana as a kind of preparatory exercise. I didn‚Äôt realize until we arrived that I was too late. Kurt Cobain had died a year earlier and with him so had the grunge movement. Seattle was starting its transformation from a gritty port into the bourgeois neo-San Francisco that it would become. And the dominant cultural phenomenon of the summer of 1995 was Starbucks, which had been founded in Seattle, in 1971, but was just starting to expand outside of the region. Starbucks was the Stumptown of the nineties, and Seattleites were proud of it and its C.E.O., Howard Schultz. I spent more of the eighth and ninth grades, after arriving in Seattle, drinking Frappuccinos‚Äîthe gateway coffee of my generation‚Äîthan I did listening to ‚ÄúIn Utero.‚Äù By the time I was in college, of course, Starbucks had lost its cachet. By creating a culture of high-end-coffee consumption in the U.S., Starbucks had encouraged the rise of smaller caf√©s, which felt cozier and sold better-tasting coffee. Also, as Starbucks had expanded, the coffee had developed a reputation for tasting burnt and too strong (some coffee snobs called it ‚ÄúCharbucks‚Äù), and the universality of the coffee shops‚Äô design made them feel like just another chain restaurant. Schultz, who announced his retirement on Thursday, likes to recall a crisis that involved the ill-conceived buildup, in the mid-aughts, of Starbucks stores. Schultz had retired for the first time in 2000, but under his successor Starbucks had expanded too fast, more than tripling the number of stores, to almost seventeen thousand, over eight years. In addition to hurting Starbucks‚Äôs reputation‚Äîthe ubiquity in itself was uncool, and the assembly-line coffee brewing was bad for quality‚Äîthis had cost too much. In 2008, as the recession made four-dollar lattes seem almost obscene, Schultz returned as C.E.O. and oversaw the decision to close six hundred stores, which would help the company ride out the recession by bringing costs under control. Schultz describes the experience in his 2011 memoir, ‚ÄúOnward‚Äù: ‚ÄúThese were not just doors we would be closing. We would be disrupting lives, on both sides of the counter.‚Äù Starbucks also shut down all its U.S. stores for a period of hours to retrain its whole staff and took other steps to insure higher-quality drinks. All this was tough, Schultz writes, but he had to do it because too many stores were just not good enough. This has since become a defining period in the company‚Äôs narrative of itself‚Äîevidence of its commitment to excellence, which, in Schultz‚Äôs telling, is the reason Starbucks has thrived since his return. Schultz‚Äôs interest in excellence persists. In leaving the C.E.O. post, he will be staying at Starbucks but focussing on Starbucks Reserve, the company‚Äôs new premium brand. The narrative about excellence has been repeated often in stories about Schultz and his company, which is odd, because it doesn‚Äôt take a Stumptown barista to know that the experience of going into a Starbucks is not particularly excellent. Starbucks‚Äôs coffee remains bad-tasting, its shops generic, its food not much better than what you‚Äôd find in a grocery store‚Äôs to-go aisle. Yet Starbucks as a business has thrived. The company reported revenue of more than twenty-one billion dollars in its 2016 fiscal year, more than double what it made the year Schultz came back. (Its stock, after falling to less than four dollars a share in 2008, is now around sixty dollars.) The reason, it turns out, is straightforward: contrary to the narrative at the center of his memoir, Schultz has spent most of his second stint at Starbucks aggressively expanding. In 2008, there were 16,680 Starbucks stores around the world. In 2009, the year of the high-profile closures, there were 16,635. And by 2010 the number had risen, again, to 16,858. Currently, the number of stores stands at more than twenty-four thousand. It‚Äôs true that Starbucks closed hundreds of low-performing stores during the recession, but it opened far more during that period, in places that didn‚Äôt already have too many Starbucks outlets and where costs could be kept down, and doubled down on that approach when the recession ended. Starbucks has especially proliferated abroad. The company has been opening five hundred stores a year in China and hopes to have five thousand there by 2021. Next year, it even plans to enter Italy, where Schultz originally found inspiration, in the eighties, to open a chain of high-end coffee shops. Schultz attributes his worldwide success to how much people love Starbucks. ‚ÄúThere are very few consumer brands in the world‚Äîproducts or experiences‚Äîthat have created both an undeniable customer attachment to the brand while also seeing universal acceptance,‚Äù he recently said. In countries like China, though, Starbucks‚Äôs success appears to have less to do with excellence than with the fact that, as in the U.S. in the nineties, coffee culture is new‚Äîand Starbucks happens to be the company introducing it. Starbucks is an excellent company in many ways. It is financially successful. The company also offers a progressive benefit system for employees, though it has sometimes been pressured into improving its workplace. Schultz has been appealingly eager to engage with messy political issues that other C.E.O.s avoid, endorsing Hillary Clinton for President and, last year, spearheading an idealistic, if ill-advised, campaign, called Race Together, encouraging baristas to discuss race with their customers. There are plenty of things that are distinctive about Starbucks. But the coffee isn‚Äôt one of them. 
Vauhini Vara, the former business editor of newyorker.com, is a contributing writer for the site. She is also an O. Henry Prize-winning fiction writer, with stories published in Tin House , ZYZZYVA , and elsewhere.

thread.title: Starbucks: Freshen the cup
thread.title_full: Starbucks: Freshen the cup

posts.title: Starbucks: Freshen the cup
posts.text:
Save December 2, 2016 
Howard Schultz of Starbucks is a frothy coffee legend. He even wrote a book about turning round the caf√© chain, entitled How Starbucks Fought For Its Life Without Losing Its Soul . 
Now Starbucks aims to lose Mr Schultz as chief executive ‚Äî he will remain chairman ‚Äî without losing its mojo, as when he previously stepped down. 
On Friday, Starbucks shares responded by dropping 2.4 per cent. The nervousness is natural. The brisk growth inspired by Mr Schultz has slowed just a touch, putting extra pressure on new boss, Kevin Johnson. 
Despite a capitalisation just shy of $83bn, Starbucks has remained a phenomenal growth story. Its revenue has grown at an annual, average rate of 13 per cent over the past five years. It will add another 2,000 outlets to its total of 25,000 next year. 
Sales at shops already open have averaged double digits in recent years. Those figures are dipping now but remain firmly positive. Former high flyers such as Chipotle and Whole Foods can only dream of such turnover. 
The concern for Starbucks is that its premium valuation ‚Äî it trades at nearly 30 times forward earnings ‚Äî will slip without Mr Schultz in charge. 
Mr Johnson is a credible successor. A board member for the past seven years and its operating chief since last year, he is a long-time technology executive. Starbucks‚Äô mobile phone app has spurred customer traffic. 
It is also questionable just how removed Mr Schultz will stay from the fray. He remains executive chairman and will focus on Starbucks‚Äô new ‚Äúhigh-end concept‚Äù (if its ordinary format is too plebeian for you). And he will also stay active on social and political issues. 
Mr Schultz‚Äôs obsessiveness, more than any other factor, is responsible for the Starbucks phenomenon. The challenge for Mr Johnson is to be equally finicky, and to such good effect that Mr Schultz steps back and lets him get on with it.

thread.title: Why I'm Bullish On Starbucks Despite Dollar Strength
thread.title_full: Why I'm Bullish On Starbucks Despite Dollar Strength

posts.title: Why I'm Bullish On Starbucks Despite Dollar Strength
posts.text:
Why I'm Bullish On Starbucks Despite Dollar Strength Dec. 3.16 Summary 
Starbucks‚Äôs performance could be hurt by a stronger dollar. 
But this risk is outweighed by its international growth opportunities and scope for improved performance in the domestic market. 
A resilient business model could help Starbucks to perform relatively well in a restaurant recession and attract investors in what could be an uncertain political and economic climate in 2017. The dollar index has reached a high of 102 in the last month . This is its highest level in over a decade and is partly due to the prospect of a more hawkish Federal Reserve operating under a Trump Presidency. His plans to reduce taxes and increase public spending could lead to inflation, which may warrant a higher interest rate. In fact, interest rates are forecast to rise to 2.25% in the next three years , which could strengthen the dollar even further. For companies such as Starbucks (NASDAQ: SBUX ) which have major (and rapidly increasing) international exposure, a stronger dollar could mean a squeeze on sales, margins and profitability. While this is a risk for the business over the medium term, I'm still bullish about Starbucks's prospects. I believe that the scale of its growth opportunity in emerging markets, its resilience in the domestic market, improving customer loyalty and greater use of technology will more than offset negative currency translation moving forward. Emerging market potential In its most recent quarter, Starbucks announced the opening of its first stores in emerging market economies such as Cambodia, Kazakhstan and Slovakia. This provides the company with a significant growth opportunity in my view, since rising wealth and disposable incomes mean that consumer goods spending is set to increase by 3.6% across the emerging world in 2016. However, Starbucks' biggest opportunity in the emerging world continues to be in larger emerging economies such as China and India, where consumer goods growth is forecast to be 9.5% and 7% respectively in 2016 . In China, Starbucks' strategy to open 500 new stores per annum over the next four years has the potential to dramatically improve its financial performance. Further, the growth rate in sales of consumer goods is expected to be around 7% over the next four years . This should provide a tailwind to Starbucks' newly opened stores. Similarly, in India Starbucks is in the process of increasing the size of its estate, while also attempting to gain exposure to the lucrative tea market. It has partnered with Tata Beverages in a joint venture which will see its Teavana products sold in over 80 tea shops across India . This is part of a wider push which will see the company attempt to gain a share of the Asia tea market and seek to generate $3 billion per annum in sales in the next five years . With China's tea market being worth $9.5 billion per annum alone , this pivot towards tea in Asia could prove to be a sound strategic move in my view. Domestic opportunities Scope for a rise in the size of Starbucks' estate in the domestic market is clearly lower than in emerging markets. The US is a more saturated market, but still offers the opportunity for Starbucks to improve its pricing power. This could help it to record higher sales and margins moving forward. One way that Starbucks is seeking to boost its pricing power in the US is through an improved customer experience. Starbucks has adopted technology to a greater extent than many of its main rivals, with the use of mobile ordering becoming increasingly popular. In fact, the proportion of Starbucks's sales which were derived from the mobile app increased from 5% to 6% in the most recent quarter. A mobile app not only improves customer convenience, it also helps to differentiate Starbucks from the competition. Dovetailing with this is Starbucks's increasingly popular customer loyalty programme. Numbers enrolled in the programme increased by 18% in Q3 and there are now over 12 million active members in the US and Canada . The loyalty programme should help to boost Starbucks's pricing power moving forward, with it also providing the company with data on shopping habits and the take-up of new products. This could help the company to decide where to locate new stores, as well as provide guidance on which products are working well with different demographics. It could lead to a more efficient business with higher sales and margins in the domestic market. Outlook As well as growth opportunities in the US and in emerging economies, Starbucks offers a relatively resilient and stable business model. Coffee is more akin to a consumer staple than a consumer good, and so is less likely to be impacted by the potential for a restaurant recession than other food and beverage outlets. Further, Starbucks has wide geographical diversity, which reduces its risk profile yet further. Given the likelihood of increased uncertainty in 2017 in both an economic and political sense from higher interest rates and a new administration, Starbucks' robust business could become more popular among increasingly risk averse investors in my view. Certainly, Starbucks' sales and profitability are likely to be affected by a stronger US dollar. With non-US sales accounting for around 20% (and rising) of Starbucks's total sales , the six rises in interest rates which are forecast over the next three years could lead to negative pressure on the company's top and bottom lines. However, in my view, Starbucks has a major growth opportunity in China, India and the emerging world which outweighs the risks of negative currency effects. Further, its opportunity to develop increased pricing power through product differentiation and higher levels of customer loyalty should positively catalyse its domestic growth. And its relatively stable business model and geographical diversity could appeal if uncertainty rises among investors in 2017. As such, I'm bullish on Starbucks in the long run despite the risks posed by a stronger dollar. If you like what you've just read, consider clicking the "Follow" link at the top of the page (next to where it says 'Team Money Research') to receive an email notification when we publish a new article. thread.title: Starbucks CEO's Deal With Trump | The Federalist Papers
thread.title_full: Starbucks CEO's Deal With Trump | The Federalist Papers

posts.author: Brian Thomas
posts.title: Starbucks CEO's Deal With Trump | The Federalist Papers
posts.text:
Pinterest 
Although Starbucks CEO, Howard Schultz, was a vocal critic of Donald Trump during his campaign, Shultz now insists his company isn‚Äôt anti-Trump. 
President Elect Donald Trump won the November election, and the American vote proves his popularity. Maybe that‚Äôs why Mr. Schultz has ended his public opposition to Trump and admits now that he is ‚Äúhopeful‚Äù and wants the president elect to do well. 
Of course, scandals involving your employees refusing to serve Trump supporters don‚Äôt leave much wiggle room for further negative publicity. 
‚ÄúThe dysfunction and the polarization we‚Äôve seen for years hopefully is not going to continue. But what‚Äôs been coming out so far is not as encouraging as one would hope,‚Äù Schultz told CNBC . 
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think on any level that the brand or what we represent is at odds with the president-elect or his supporters,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúNinety million customers a week are going through Starbucks stores, and I assume many of them voted for Donald Trump.‚Äù 
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not spending a lot of time on the cause and the effect of the Trump administration,‚Äù Schultz also told CNBC on Friday. ‚ÄúObviously we all want the president-elect to do well, but Starbucks is going to have to do what we do based on the things that we can control.‚Äù 
Walking the razor edge of pleasing liberals without discouraging conservative consumers leaves Schultz abandoning his former dump-on-Trump rhetoric for carefully safeguarded PR scripts. 
He at least knows now that public opinion isn‚Äôt favorable of lambasting Donald Trump. He‚Äôs made it very clear that Starbucks shouldn‚Äôt be seen as at odds with the President Elect. 
The Washington Post reports: 
Throughout the presidential campaign, Schultz made it no secret that he supported Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton , formally endorsing her in September. In a letter to Starbucks staff after Election Day, Schultz admitted he was ‚Äústunned‚Äù when Trump won ‚Äî and called on Starbucks ‚Äúpartners‚Äù to choose to treat others with kindness, compassion and respect. 
‚ÄúWe cannot know what the precise impact will be on our country and the rest of the world,‚Äù Schultz wrote then . ‚ÄúI am hopeful that we will overcome the vitriol and division of this unprecedented election season.‚Äù 
Schultz also announced last week that he plans to resign as the company‚Äôs CEO to become executive chairman starting in April. 
Let us know what you think of Shultz‚Äôs turnaround, and sound off in the comments below!

Starbucks customers have been enjoying the 2016 holiday cups for nearly a month now ‚Äì and the coffee company just launched a hot new winter beverage to accompany them.
Starting Dec. 2, Starbucks stores will offer their newest drink: Snickerdoodle Hot Cocoa.
SEE ALSO: After last year's drama, Starbucks unveils holiday cups designed by 13 women
Snickerdoodle Hot Cocoa is, "made with steamed milk, white chocolate mocha sauce and cinnamon dolce syrup topped with whipped cream and a dusting of cinnamon sugar," Starbucks explained in a release sent to Mashable .
View photos
Image: starbucks
The new beverage joins three other cocoas on Starbucks' menu: Peppermint Hot Cocoa, Salted Caramel Hot Cocoa and White Chocolate Hot Cocoa.
And in case a hot cocoa isn't enough sweetness for you, participating U.S. Starbucks stores are offering $1 cake pops with the purchase of any hot chocolate through Dec. 25.
Several varieties of Starbucks' hot cocoa are also available in stores.
View photos
Double Chocolate Hot Cocoa Mix, Salted Caramel Hot Cocoa Mix, Marshmallow Hot Cocoa Mix and Peppermint Hot Cocoa Mix. More Image: starbucks
Starbucks, thank you for enabling sweet teeth all across the world.
BONUS: Are You For or Against the Pumpkin Spice Latte?

thread.title: Howard Schultz stepping down as Starbucks CEO | 12NEWS.com
thread.title_full: Howard Schultz stepping down as Starbucks CEO | 12NEWS.com

posts.title: Howard Schultz stepping down as Starbucks CEO | 12NEWS.com
posts.text:
Howard Schultz stepping down as Starbucks CEO King 5 Associated Pres , KING 3:50 AM. MST December 03, 2016 Starbucks Chairman and CEO Howard Schultz speaks during Starbucks annual shareholders meeting March 18, 2015 in Seattle, Washington. (Photo: Stephen Brashear/Getty Images) (Photo: 2015 Getty Images) 
NEW YORK - Starbucks says CEO Howard Schultz is stepping down from the coffee chain that he joined more than 30 years ago. The Seattle-based company announced Thursday that Kevin Johnson will become chief executive as of April 3. Schultz will become executive chairman on that date to focus on innovation and social impact activities, among other things. Shares of Starbucks slid 3.6 percent to $56.44 in after-hours trading. Johnson, currently president and chief operating officer, will take charge of the company's global business and operations. He joined the Starbucks board in 2009 and has spent years at technology companies including 16 years with Microsoft and five as Juniper Networks CEO.

thread.title: Howard Schultz Says Goodbye to His Starbucks Empire
thread.title_full: Howard Schultz Says Goodbye to His Starbucks Empire - The New Yorker

posts.author: newyorker.com
posts.title: Howard Schultz Says Goodbye to His Starbucks Empire
posts.text:
The departing Starbucks C.E.O. Howard Schultz‚Äôs narrative about his company is one of excellence and focus, but it‚Äôs really one of unrelenting expansion. Credit PHOTOGRAPH BY SPENCER PLATT / GETTY In the summer of 1995, when my parents told my sister and me that we‚Äôd be moving to Seattle, I started listening to Nirvana as a kind of preparatory exercise. I didn‚Äôt realize until we arrived that I was too late. Kurt Cobain had died a year earlier and with him so had the grunge movement. Seattle was starting its transformation from a gritty port into the bourgeois neo-San Francisco that it would become. And the dominant cultural phenomenon of the summer of 1995 was Starbucks, which had been founded in Seattle, in 1971, but was just starting to expand outside of the region. Starbucks was the Stumptown of the nineties, and Seattleites were proud of it and its C.E.O., Howard Schultz. I spent more of the eighth and ninth grades, after arriving in Seattle, drinking Frappuccinos‚Äîthe gateway coffee of my generation‚Äîthan I did listening to ‚ÄúIn Utero.‚Äù By the time I was in college, of course, Starbucks had lost its cachet. By creating a culture of high-end-coffee consumption in the U.S., Starbucks had encouraged the rise of smaller caf√©s, which felt cozier and sold better-tasting coffee. Also, as Starbucks had expanded, the coffee had developed a reputation for tasting burnt and too strong (some coffee snobs called it ‚ÄúCharbucks‚Äù), and the universality of the coffee shops‚Äô design made them feel like just another chain restaurant.
Schultz, who announced his retirement on Thursday, likes to recall a crisis that involved the ill-conceived buildup, in the mid-aughts, of Starbucks stores. Schultz had retired for the first time in 2000, but under his successor Starbucks had expanded too fast, more than tripling the number of stores, to almost seventeen thousand, over eight years. In addition to hurting Starbucks‚Äôs reputation‚Äîthe ubiquity in itself was uncool, and the assembly-line coffee brewing was bad for quality‚Äîthis had cost too much. In 2008, as the recession made four-dollar lattes seem almost obscene, Schultz returned as C.E.O. and oversaw the decision to close six hundred stores, which would help the company ride out the recession by bringing costs under control. Schultz describes the experience in his 2011 memoir, ‚ÄúOnward‚Äù: ‚ÄúThese were not just doors we would be closing. We would be disrupting lives, on both sides of the counter.‚Äù Starbucks also shut down all its U.S. stores for a period of hours to retrain its whole staff and took other steps to insure higher-quality drinks. All this was tough, Schultz writes, but he had to do it because too many stores were just not good enough. This has since become a defining period in the company‚Äôs narrative of itself‚Äîevidence of its commitment to excellence, which, in Schultz‚Äôs telling, is the reason Starbucks has thrived since his return. Schultz‚Äôs interest in excellence persists. In leaving the C.E.O. post, he will be staying at Starbucks but focussing on Starbucks Reserve, the company‚Äôs new premium brand.
The narrative about excellence has been repeated often in stories about Schultz and his company, which is odd, because it doesn‚Äôt take a Stumptown barista to know that the experience of going into a Starbucks is not particularly excellent. Starbucks‚Äôs coffee remains bad-tasting, its shops generic, its food not much better than what you‚Äôd find in a grocery store‚Äôs to-go aisle. Yet Starbucks as a business has thrived. The company reported revenue of more than twenty-one billion dollars in its 2016 fiscal year, more than double what it made the year Schultz came back. (Its stock, after falling to less than four dollars a share in 2008, is now around sixty dollars.) The reason, it turns out, is straightforward: contrary to the narrative at the center of his memoir, Schultz has spent most of his second stint at Starbucks aggressively expanding. In 2008, there were 16,680 Starbucks stores around the world. In 2009, the year of the high-profile closures, there were 16,635. And by 2010 the number had risen, again, to 16,858. Currently, the number of stores stands at more than twenty-four thousand. It‚Äôs true that Starbucks closed hundreds of low-performing stores during the recession, but it opened far more during that period, in places that didn‚Äôt already have too many Starbucks outlets and where costs could be kept down, and doubled down on that approach when the recession ended.
Starbucks has especially proliferated abroad. The company has been opening five hundred stores a year in China and hopes to have five thousand there by 2021. Next year, it even plans to enter Italy, where Schultz originally found inspiration, in the eighties, to open a chain of high-end coffee shops. Schultz attributes his worldwide success to how much people love Starbucks. ‚ÄúThere are very few consumer brands in the world‚Äîproducts or experiences‚Äîthat have created both an undeniable customer attachment to the brand while also seeing universal acceptance,‚Äù he recently said. In countries like China, though, Starbucks‚Äôs success appears to have less to do with excellence than with the fact that, as in the U.S. in the nineties, coffee culture is new‚Äîand Starbucks happens to be the company introducing it. Starbucks is an excellent company in many ways. It is financially successful. The company also offers a progressive benefit system for employees, though it has sometimes been pressured into improving its workplace. Schultz has been appealingly eager to engage with messy political issues that other C.E.O.s avoid, endorsing Hillary Clinton for President and, last year, spearheading an idealistic, if ill-advised, campaign, called Race Together, encouraging baristas to discuss race with their customers. There are plenty of things that are distinctive about Starbucks. But the coffee isn‚Äôt one of them.
