thread.title: Starbucks CEO says company isn‚Äôt anti-Trump: ‚ÄòWe all want the president-elect to do well‚Äô
thread.title_full: Starbucks CEO says company isn‚Äôt anti-Trump: ‚ÄòWe all want the president-elect to do well‚Äô

posts.author: Amy B Wang
posts.title: Starbucks CEO says company isn‚Äôt anti-Trump: ‚ÄòWe all want the president-elect to do well‚Äô
posts.text:
Starbucks CEO says company isn‚Äôt anti-Trump: ‚ÄòWe all want the president-elect to do well‚Äô The Washington Post 2 hrs ago Amy B Wang Click to expand Replay Video Sheriff on Oakland fire: This is a tragedy, no easy answers Aalmeda County Sheriff, Sgt. Ray Kelly, gives the latest update on the deadly fire at a warehouse in Oakland, California. MSNBC Firefighters battle major fire in Cambridge, Mass. Reuters Castro funeral cortege reaches destination The late Fidel Castro's funeral cortege arrived in Santiago de Cuba on Saturday, ahead of a ceremony to mark his life on Sunday. Nathan Frandino reports. Reuters America Play Schultz: Starbucks brand not at odds with Trump CNBC See more videos SHARE SHARE TWEET SHARE EMAIL What to watch next Sheriff on Oakland fire: This is a tragedy, no easy answers MSNBC 2:03 Firefighters battle major fire in Cambridge, Mass. Reuters 3:23 Castro funeral cortege reaches destination Reuters America 1:09 Driver live-streams 104 mph crash CNN 0:59 Family of murdered teen shares their heartache WCVB Boston 1:47 Tribe elders, U.S. veterans protest pipeline Reuters America 1:00 Trump-themed treats attract attention from the couple's lawyers Reuters America 1:14 Shooter who killed former NFL player released without charges CBS News 1:49 Nine dead, many more missing, in California party fire Reuters America 0:59 Trump's risky phone call with Taiwan could anger China CBS News 2:58 Remains of crash victims being returned to Brazil CNN 1:53 As bombs fall on eastern Aleppo, world leaders plea for peace Reuters 1:27 Trump says Philippines fighting drugs 'the right way': Duterte AFP 0:47 How can Trump avoid potential business conflicts? CBS News 4:00 Bus carrying cheerleaders crashes, 8 taken to hospital Reuters America 0:31 America has a new favorite poet MSNBC 7:02 UP NEXT Starbucks chief executive Howard Schultz, a vocal critic of Donald Trump during the election, said he is not concerned about the effect of the president-elect ‚Äî or of his supporters ‚Äî on the massive coffee chain‚Äôs business.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not spending a lot of time on the cause and the effect of the Trump administration,‚Äù Schultz said Friday on CNBC . ‚ÄúObviously we all want the president-elect to do well, but Starbucks is going to have to do what we do based on the things that we can control.‚Äù
Throughout the presidential campaign, Schultz made it no secret that he supported Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton , formally endorsing her in September. In a letter to Starbucks staff after Election Day, Schultz admitted he was ‚Äústunned‚Äù when Trump won ‚Äî and called on Starbucks ‚Äúpartners‚Äù to choose to treat others with kindness, compassion and respect.
‚ÄúWe cannot know what the precise impact will be on our country and the rest of the world,‚Äù Schultz wrote then . ‚ÄúI am hopeful that we will overcome the vitriol and division of this unprecedented election season.‚Äù
Since the bitter and divisive election came to an end last month, there have been numerous incidents reported at various Starbucks stores involving Trump supporters.
Recently, video of Florida resident David Sanguesa berating a Starbucks barista went viral . Sanguesa claimed afterward that he had been the victim of ‚Äúanti-white discrimination‚Äù and that the employee refused to serve him because he was a Trump supporter. (‚ÄúBecause I voted for Trump! Trump! You lost! Now give me my money back,‚Äù Sanguesa can be heard shouting at the barista in the video. ‚ÄúWhat is your name? I want your name. I want your card. You‚Äôre garbage. You‚Äôre complete trash.‚Äù)
A witness said Sanguesa simply got angry because his coffee order took too long.
Around the same time, video surfaced of a Starbucks barista at a different location refusing to write ‚ÄúTrump‚Äù on someone‚Äôs cup . Soon afterward, Los Angeles political consultant Tim Treadstone urged his social-media followers to launch ‚ÄúOperation #TrumpCup‚Äù ‚Äî that is, to visit Starbucks, ask them to write ‚ÄúTrump‚Äù on their cups and to take video if any employees refused.
¬© Stephen Brashear/Getty Images Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz speaks at the Starbucks Annual Shareholders Meeting on Mar. 23 in Seattle. On CNBC, Schultz directly addressed questions of whether such incidents might indicate Starbucks and its corporate values meant the chain was ‚Äúat odds‚Äù with Trump and his supporters.
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think on any level that the brand or what we represent is at odds with the president-elect or his supporters,‚Äù Schultz told CNBC. ‚ÄúNinety million customers a week are going through Starbucks stores, and I assume many of them voted for Donald Trump.‚Äù
He added that the business needed to separate its prospects ‚Äúfrom the Trump administration and the momentum in the stock market‚Äù but would also continue to push on ‚Äúa number of social issues.‚Äù
Schultz did not elaborate on what those issues might be, only saying that they have not been addressed by Republican administrations in the past and that he hoped Trump would address them in his administration.
‚ÄúI think that as we go forward we will have an active voice in demonstrating the moral courage to address things that we think are important to the promise of America and the American Dream,‚Äù Schultz said.
His comments were in line with Schultz‚Äôs long record of getting involved in social or political issues, sometimes at the risk of alienating customers.
Last year, Starbucks urged baristas to write ‚ÄúRace Together‚Äù on the sides of its coffee cups, in an effort to engage customers in difficult conversations about race relations in America. The campaign sparked criticism and even ridicule online but had seemingly little effect at the store level . And each year, whether intentionally or not, Starbucks finds itself in the middle of a heated debate over what, exactly, the color of its holiday coffee cup is supposed to mean .
Starbucks‚Äô plain-red holiday cup last year attracted the ire of none other than Trump himself, who suggested to his supporters at a rally last November to boycott the coffee chain .
‚ÄúDid you read about Starbucks?‚Äù Trump asked the crowd in Springfield, Ill., to loud boos. ‚ÄúNo more ‚ÄòMerry Christmas‚Äô at Starbucks. No more. ‚Ä¶ Maybe we should boycott Starbucks.‚Äù
Starbucks is no stranger to such cultural debates, as The Washington Post‚Äôs Maura Judkis noted :
The culture wars come every December, fueled by peppermint mochas and venti soy lattes. The battleground is Starbucks. It‚Äôs always Starbucks, isn‚Äôt it? No one is complaining that the blue-and-brown holiday cups at Caribou Coffee take the ‚ÄúChrist‚Äù out of Christmas. No one is telling the Olive Garden hostess that their name is ‚ÄúTrump‚Äù so that she will have to call out ‚ÄúTrump, party of three!‚Äù
Religion. Politics. The Bill of Rights. They all converge here, in front of a glass case full of cake pops.
Schultz will step aside as CEO next April to focus on other Starbucks corporate initiatives, the company announced last Thursday . Kevin Johnson, the company‚Äôs chief operating officer, will take over as CEO then. Schultz plans to stay on as chairman.
Read more:
‚ÄòWe have a culture war to win‚Äô: Why Starbucks cups always stir up controversy
‚ÄòAnd I voted for Trump! So there!‚Äô: Woman accuses black Michaels employees of discrimination
‚ÄòDo not say mean things‚Äô: Kids are writing to Donald Trump, asking him to be a kind president
Go to MSN Home

thread.title: Starbucks‚Äô New Hot Apple Pie Latte Can Only Be Purchased In Japan Because We Can‚Äôt Have Nice Things
thread.title_full: Starbucks‚Äô New Hot Apple Pie Latte Can Only Be Purchased In Japan Because We Can‚Äôt Have Nice Things

posts.author: RecruitmentChairTSM
posts.title: Starbucks‚Äô New Hot Apple Pie Latte Can Only Be Purchased In Japan Because We Can‚Äôt Have Nice Things
posts.text:
Columns ¬ª   Starbucks‚Äô New Hot Apple Pie Latte Can Only Be Purchased In Japan Because We Can‚Äôt Have Nice Things   
Ever since PSL season ended, there‚Äôs been a significant void in my life. Sure, I‚Äôve been trying to fill it with endless skinny peppermint mochas and gingerbread lattes, but there‚Äôs just something about combining seasonal spices and produce with hot coffee and warm steamed milk that fills your soul with joy. For coffee lovers in Japan, you‚Äôre in luck, because Starbucks just came out with an amazing hot apple pie latte that will keep you as warm inside as your favorite holiday sweater. Unfortunately for the rest of us, we‚Äôll just have to figure out how to live without it. 
Image via Starbucks 
If you ever wanted to pull a Shoshana, now is definitely the time because, like all of Starbucks‚Äô other limited-edition drinks, this one won‚Äôt last long. In case you‚Äôre more of a cold beverage drinker, Starbs Japan will also be offering the hot apple pie latte in frappucino form, which looks like it contains actual apple pie pieces in it. Honestly, if I would have known that I could get the pie without all of the questions from relatives about why I‚Äôm not married yet, I probably would have given Thanksgiving a pass this year. Maybe it‚Äôs a good thing I won‚Äôt be able to get my hands on it after all. 
Missing out on this latte definitely sucks, but on the bright side, Starbucks just came out with yet another limited-edition drink for the U.S. to help us get through these dark and dangerous times. Hot chocolate and cookie lovers, head over to your nearest coffee shop for a red cup or twelve, because Starbs has just released a new snickerdoodle hot chocolate, which sounds like everything dreams are made of. Combining white chocolate with cinnamon dolce syrup with a sprinkle of the same cinnamon sugar everyone‚Äôs favorite cookie is rolled in has created the most magical drink you didn‚Äôt know you needed this holiday season. For extra holiday spirit, pair with a Starbucks toffeedoodle cookie and Instagram the shit out of that red cup ‚Äì just do yourself a favor and try not to check the nutrition facts, ok?

thread.title: Here's what happened the last time Howard Schultz stepped down as Starbucks CEO ($SBUX)
thread.title_full: Here's what happened the last time Howard Schultz stepped down as Starbucks CEO ($SBUX)

posts.author: Kate Taylor
posts.title: Here's what happened the last time Howard Schultz stepped down as Starbucks CEO ($SBUX)
posts.text:
Howard Schultz. Stephen Brashear / Stringer / Getty Images 
On Thursday, Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz announced he is stepping down next year. 
This isn't the first time Schultz, who first joined Starbucks in 1982, has stepped down from his position as CEO. It also happened 16 years ago ‚Äî and it was a disaster for the coffee chain. 
In 2000, Schultz stepped down after a 13-year run as CEO. He assumed the role of chairman, with the mission of focusing on the company's global strategy. 
Then Starbucks had only 2,800 stores and earned roughly $2 billion in annual revenue. There were just 350 Starbucks locations outside the US. 
In the seven weeks after Schultz stepped down in 2000, shares fell 28%, MarketWatch reported. 
But the company soon began a steady recovery. Under Schultz's replacement, Orin Smith, Starbucks' business exploded, with store count tripling to 9,000 locations. Starbucks made more than $5 billion in annual total net revenue in fiscal 2004. 
Flickr / kristina dymond 
Smith retired in 2005, and was replaced by Jim Donald. At the time, Schultz said Donald was picked for his stamina and hands-on approach, which Starbucks hoped would be assets as the chain swiftly expanded and built its food business. By 2007, the company had roughly 13,000 locations worldwide. 
Soon, however, it became clear that Starbucks' had opened too many stores too quickly. With increased pressure from brands like McDonald's and Dunkin' Donuts, the chain struggled to continue to attract new customers and grow sales. 
"I have said for 20 years that our success is not an entitlement and now it's proving to be a reality," Schultz wrote in a leaked memo to Donald in February 2007. In the note he said the chain had watered down its brand with changes such as automatic espresso machines and more "sterile" store designs. 
Howard Schultz and Jim Donald Bloomberg/AP 
Starbucks stock plummeted 42% in 2007 as the Great Recession took hold. 
"The damage was slow and quiet, incremental, like a single loose thread that unravels a sweater inch by inch," Schultz said of Starbucks' troubles in his book, Onward . 
In January 2008, Starbucks fired Donald and Schultz returned as CEO. 
Schultz debuted an aggressive turnaround plan with steps that included temporarily closing all US stores to re-train employees on how to make an espresso. Starbucks appointed the company's first chief technology officer and debuted its now legendary Starbucks' rewards card. In early 2009, the company closed 600 under-preforming US stores, 70% of which had been open for three years or less. 
Within two years of Schultz's return, the company was back on track. Starbucks' stock hit a then all-time-high in mid-2011, beating its previous record set in 2006. The company's stock reached its peak of $ 62.61 in October 2015 . 
The company's struggles from 2000 to 2008 make Schultz's recent decision to step down as CEO seem like an uneasy proposition for the company. However, Schultz has said his exit as CEO will be very different in 2016 than it was in 2000. 
Starbucks 
"The differences between then and now couldn't be greater. In 2007, 2008, the country was going through a cataclysmic financial crisis that affected all companies, especially consumer brands, and Starbucks was not immune," Schultz said in a call with investors on Thursday. 
Schultz said he believes Starbucks' management team today has capabilities and experience the company lacked in 2000. 
"On a personal level, I don't think I was as prepared then as I am now, primarily because of my confidence in the strategy, my confidence in the team, and my deep deep respect for Kevin Johnson as a servant leader," Schultz said. 
Schultz may now take a more hands-on approach to his role on the board than he did in the past, a period during which he said he "wasn't engaged" enough to notice and halt the company's downfall. 
"I'm not leaving the company. I'm here every single day," he said in Thursday's call.

posts.title: Starbucks CEO Steps Down To Focus On High-End Coffee, Shares Fall
posts.text: Starbucks CEO Steps Down To Focus On High-End Coffee, Shares Fall World | Reuters | Updated: December 05, 2016 01:14 IST EMAIL COMMENTS Starbucks Chief Executive Howard Schultz speaks during their annual shareholders meeting (Reuters) Starbucks Corp co-founder Howard Schultz will step down as chief executive to focus on new high-end coffee shops, handing the top job to Chief Operating Officer Kevin Johnson, a long-time technology executive.Schultz, who will become executive chairman in April 2017, said he would focus on building ultra-premium Reserve stores and showcase Roastery and Tasting Rooms around the world as well as setting the brand's "social impact agenda" that includes sending employees to college and recruiting veterans.Starbucks had signaled the change in July, but its shares fell 3.6 percent to $56.41 in extended trading on Thursday, as investors recalled the company's decline after Schultz handed over the reins in 2000. He returned in 2008."Having him step down as CEO raised the anxiety level," said Stephens analyst Will Slabaugh, who said that Schultz is the heart and soul of the brand, its entrepreneurial leader and its savior."We're in a much better position on every level," said Schultz, who returned for his second stint as CEO in the depths of the "Great Recession," when Starbucks' stock was trading below $10. Late last year, it hit an all-time high above $60. Schultz has put Starbucks in the national spotlight, asking customers not to bring guns into stores and urging conversations on race relations.Many of the campaigns have generated controversy, but analysts have not seen a hit to financial results and the efforts have raised the profile of the coffee company and cemented Schultz's status as a national figure."The idea that he's replaceable, I think that's erroneous," said Bill Smead, CEO of Smead Capital Management in Seattle, which owns Starbucks shares. He compared the change to the retirement of long-time McDonald's Corp CEO Ray Kroc, who turned a handful of hamburger stands into the world's biggest restaurant company.The announcement on Thursday also came as investors worry about the restaurant industry's stubborn traffic declines. Starbucks has held up better than most, but it has not been immune.Johnson is a former technology executive who became president and chief operating officer at Starbucks in March 2015.Johnson has been on the Starbucks board since 2009 but most of his career was in the technology industry. He was the chief executive of Juniper Networks Inc from September 2008 to January 2014 and prior to that held several senior positions at Microsoft Corp.On a conference call after the announcement, analysts pressed the company on timing and whether, with Schultz stepping aside, senior management still had the "merchant gene.""Not having retail experience could be a problem over time," said Howard Penney, an analyst at Hedgeye Risk Management."I'm not leaving the company and I'm here every day," said Schultz, whose office is connected to Johnson's.Traffic at established Starbucks cafes fell in the last quarter, which Johnson has attributed to a change in the company's loyalty program, and Starbucks forecast a mid-single-digit rise in 2017 same-store sales.The company dismissed speculation that Schultz could be preparing for a new career in politics."He has no plans to run for political office, as he has said many times, and will remain with the company as Starbucks executive chairman, focusing on premium coffee," a spokeswoman said.(Reporting by Gayathree Ganesan and Siddharth Cavale in Bengaluru; additional writing by Peter Henderson; Editing by Bill Rigby and Jonathan Oatis) √Ç≈† Thomson Reuters 2016 (This story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.) posts.title: Starbucks CEO steps down to focus on high-end coffee, shares fall
posts.text: Tweet Share FILE PHOTO: Starbucks Chief Executive Howard Schultz speaks during the company's annual shareholders meeting in Seattle, Washington March 18, 2015. REUTERS/David Ryder/Files More By Lisa Baertlein and Gayathree Ganesan (Reuters) - Starbucks Corp co-founder Howard Schultz will step down as chief executive to focus on new high-end coffee shops, handing the top job to Chief Operating Officer Kevin Johnson, a long-time technology executive. Schultz, who will become executive chairman in April 2017, said he would focus on building ultra-premium Reserve stores and showcase Roastery and Tasting Rooms around the world as well as setting the brand's "social impact agenda" that includes sending employees to college and recruiting veterans. Starbucks had signaled the change in July, but its shares fell 3.6 percent to $56.41 in extended trading on Thursday, as investors recalled the company's decline after Schultz handed over the reins in 2000. He returned in 2008. "Having him step down as CEO raised the anxiety level," said Stephens analyst Will Slabaugh, who said that Schultz is the heart and soul of the brand, its entrepreneurial leader and its savior. "We're in a much better position on every level," said Schultz, who returned for his second stint as CEO in the depths of the "Great Recession," when Starbucks' stock was trading below $10. Late last year, it hit an all-time high above $60. Schultz has put Starbucks in the national spotlight, asking customers not to bring guns into stores and urging conversations on race relations. Many of the campaigns have generated controversy, but analysts have not seen a hit to financial results and the efforts have raised the profile of the coffee company and cemented Schultz's status as a national figure. "The idea that he's replaceable, I think that's erroneous," said Bill Smead, CEO of Smead Capital Management in Seattle, which owns Starbucks shares. He compared the change to the retirement of long-time McDonald's Corp CEO Ray Kroc, who turned a handful of hamburger stands into the world's biggest restaurant company. The announcement on Thursday also came as investors worry about the restaurant industry's stubborn traffic declines. Starbucks has held up better than most, but it has not been immune. Johnson is a former technology executive who became president and chief operating officer at Starbucks in March 2015. Johnson has been on the Starbucks board since 2009 but most of his career was in the technology industry. He was the chief executive of Juniper Networks Inc from September 2008 to January 2014 and prior to that held several senior positions at Microsoft Corp. On a conference call after the announcement, analysts pressed the company on timing and whether, with Schultz stepping aside, senior management still had the "merchant gene." "Not having retail experience could be a problem over time," said Howard Penney, an analyst at Hedgeye Risk Management. "I'm not leaving the company and I'm here every day," said Schultz, whose office is connected to Johnson's. Traffic at established Starbucks cafes fell in the last quarter, which Johnson has attributed to a change in the company's loyalty program, and Starbucks forecast a mid-single-digit rise in 2017 same-store sales. The company dismissed speculation that Schultz could be preparing for a new career in politics. "He has no plans to run for political office, as he has said many times, and will remain with the company as Starbucks executive chairman, focusing on premium coffee," a spokeswoman said. (Reporting by Gayathree Ganesan and Siddharth Cavale in Bengaluru; additional writing by Peter Henderson; Editing by Bill Rigby and Jonathan Oatis) Reblog

thread.title: Shake Shack Is Quickly Becoming the Next Starbucks in One Major Area
thread.title_full: Shake Shack Is Quickly Becoming the Next Starbucks in One Major Area - TheStreet

posts.author: Brian Sozzi
posts.title: Shake Shack Is Quickly Becoming the Next Starbucks in One Major Area
posts.text:
Ever so quietly, Shake Shack ( SHAK ) is quickly becoming the Starbucks ( SBUX ) of mobile ordering hamburgers and shakes.
The upstart better burger chain has expanded its new mobile ordering capability to 27 locations out of its total of 56 in the U.S., according to data compiled by TheStreet . Most recently, Shake Shack has debuted the service in several locations in Philadelphia.
Shake Shack's biggest push has come in its home market of New York (also its largest), where mobile ordering is live in nine out of 18 sites. Mobile ordering is still not available in Shake Shack's busiest New York City locations such as Grand Central Terminal, Herald Square and birthplace in Madison Square Park. That's likely in large part due to executives trying to figure out how to solve the operational challenges of servicing the crazy long lines at these high-profile spots while also being inundated with mobile orders.
But, there soon may be a test site on how to pull off such a feat.
"It [mobile ordering] will be here [Penn Station] soon--you'll see mobile ordering coming to every Shake Shack," Shake Shack's senior vice president of operations Zach Koff told TheStreet in an interview (video below) ahead of the opening of the company's new location in busy transit hub Penn Station on Saturday. "It will be super critical at a place like Penn Station--you could sit on the train and order and then have it ready when you arrive," Koff added.

thread.title: Starbucks Shares Plunge As CEO Unexpectedly Steps Down
thread.title_full: Starbucks Shares Plunge As CEO Unexpectedly Steps Down

posts.title: Starbucks Shares Plunge As CEO Unexpectedly Steps Down
posts.text:
Starbucks Shares Plunge As CEO Unexpectedly Steps Down December 01, 2016, 04:54:27 PM EDT By ETF Daily News Shutterstock photo 
Effective April 3, Schultz will move to the Executive Chairman position, and Kevin Johnson, who is the current Chief Operating Officer, take over as CEO. 
As Executive Chairman, Schultz "will shift his focus to innovation, design and development of Starbucks Reserve Roasteries around the world, expansion of the Starbucks Reserve retail store format and the company's social impact initiatives," the company said. Shultz will also remain as chairman of the Board. 
Shultz's roots with Starbucks reach all the way back to 1981, when he joined the fledgling single coffee shop as its marketing head. Under his leadership, the brand grew from a single small store to a massive multinational corporation. He left for a hiatus in the early 2000s but returned as CEO in 2008. 
New CEO Kevin Johnson has served as COO since mid 2015, and has overseen many duties of the company in that timeframe. 
Starbucks shares fell $2.36 (-4.03%) to $56.15 in after-hours trading on Thursday. Prior to today's management shake-up, SBUX had already fallen -2.53% year-to-date, versus a +7.7% gain in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period. 
    ETF Daily News

thread.title: The five spot: 5 ways the departing Starbucks CEO made his mark
thread.title_full: The five spot: 5 ways the departing Starbucks CEO made his mark

posts.author: From the Editorial Board
posts.title: The five spot: 5 ways the departing Starbucks CEO made his mark
posts.text:
Five legacies of Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz. 

1.He firmly anchored Seattle‚Äôs civic identity on overpriced coffee, and ditched quaint relics such as an overpriced pro basketball team . 

2. He took care of his workforce with college benefits , health care and a daily wellness regimen of tai chai and frappa-chin-ups. 

3. He founded a global culture based on expensive beverage addiction, cutting across ethnicity, tribe and religion. He dared to enter unreached and repressive societies as farflung as China , Egypt and Spokane. 

4.He stood tall for family values by resisting America‚Äôs bikini barista trend, and by covering the topless mermaid on the original Starbucks cup . 

5. He helped lazy men everywhere by popularizing the world‚Äôs most impersonal fallback option: the Starbucks gift card. Related content
